message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sickle cell anemia causes an increased susceptibility to infections with certain organisms, particularly encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae type B, and Neisseria meningitidis. C3 complement deficiency also causes an increased susceptibility to infections with these organisms, while C5-9 complement deficiency primarily causes an increased susceptibility to Neisseria infections. T-cell deficiency and hemophilia A do not cause a similar pattern of increased susceptibility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients with sickle cell anemia have a higher risk of infections, particularly with encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis. Similarly, patients with C3 complement deficiency are also at increased risk for infections with encapsulated bacteria. Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder, and T-cell deficiency can also increase susceptibility to infections but it is not specifically related to encapsulated bacteria. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) C3 complement deficiency.

We refer to a medical article on sickle cell anemia for help. Patients with sickle cell anemia are susceptible to infections with encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae. Among the options, only C3 complement deficiency has a similar pattern of increased susceptibility to these same organisms.

We refer to other reliable sources for help. Patients with sickle cell anemia have an increased susceptibility to infections by encapsulated organisms, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae type B. Similarly, patients with C3 complement deficiency have an increased susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria, while patients with C5-9 complement deficiency have an increased susceptibility to Neisseria infections. T-cell deficiencies lead to a variety of infections, including viral, fungal, and opportunistic infections. Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder and does not affect susceptibility to infections. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) C3 complement deficiency.

Similarly, patients with C3 complement deficiency also have an increased risk of infection with encapsulated organisms. T-cell deficiency and hemophilia A do not typically present with this pattern of increased susceptibility.

Patients with sickle cell anemia have an increased susceptibility to infections by encapsulated organisms due to a deficiency in functional spleen. Similarly, patients with C3 complement deficiency have an increased susceptibility to infections with encapsulated organisms. The other options do not have a similar pattern of increased susceptibility.

Patients with sickle cell anemia have an increased susceptibility to infection with certain organisms, particularly those encapsulated by a polysaccharide capsule. C3 complement deficiency also leads to an increased susceptibility to infections with encapsulated organisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sickle cell anemia patients have an increased susceptibility to infections with encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae type b, which is also seen in patients with C3 complement deficiency. The other options listed do not have a similar pattern of increased susceptibility to these organisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients with sickle cell anemia are more susceptible to infections with encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, and this pattern is also seen in patients with C3 complement deficiency who have a similar increased risk of infections with encapsulated bacteria. Option A is incorrect because C5-9 complement deficiency leads to increased susceptibility to Neisseria infections. Option B is incorrect because T-cell deficiency leads to increased susceptibility to viral, fungal, and intracellular bacterial pathogens. Option D is incorrect because hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder and does not affect the immune system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients with sickle cell anemia have an increased susceptibility to infections with encapsulated organisms, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, due to a deficiency in complement component C3. C5-9 complement deficiency is associated with increased susceptibility to Neisseria meningitidis. T-cell deficiency is associated with increased susceptibility to viral, fungal, and intracellular bacterial infections. Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder and not associated with increased susceptibility to infections.
